subject: Re: [junit] message "null"
msgSnippet: ... The string characters are /already/ in character arrays, are they not? No extra putting is required. ... I don t know what it s like now, but I do know
messageBody:
On Thursday 29 June 2006 16:18, Kamal Ahmed wrote:

> The equals() method compares the characters that make up String objects. It
> performs this comparison by putting the characters of the String objects
> into two char arrays and comparing the two arrays.

The string characters are /already/ in character arrays, are they not? No
extra "putting" is required.

> The == operator compares two object references to see whether they refer to
> the same instance. A pool of strings, initially empty, is maintained
> privately by the class String. All literal strings and string-valued
> constant expressions are interned there. You can also add your own strings
> to this pool by calling the intern() method.

I don't know what it's like now, but I do know that a few years ago the pool
was small enough that you could overflow it relatively easily.

--
Chris "rant about /no symbol type/ suppressed" Dollin
"Who do you serve, and who do you trust?" /Crusade/
